transcript.speaker: Susan Davis

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: Hi. I also have sunscreen recommendations for later if you want them.

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: (Laughter) First I want to start off with what I would ask you, is that my favorite kind of summer read is just the frothy page-turner, the one book that everyone's reading that HBO or Netflix is going to turn into a movie or TV show sometime next year.

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: You want your basic "Gone Girl."

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: You want your "Big Little Lies."

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: Exactly.

And her mother does something very, very surprising for a lady who is described as knowing where all the tops to the Tupperware are, which is that she very calmly and coolly kills him.

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: What is that called again? Just remind me.

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: It's called "Pieces Of Her," by Karin Slaughter. But if you're waiting for the next book like that that's coming out, the hottest off the press, I would recommend "Bunny" by Mona Awad, which is also very funny and very sharp and an extremely readable page-turner, which is coming out in June.

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: I also think about summer reading as escapism fiction. You know, you want to go to another world or back in time or fantasy novels. What about that?

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: A throwback.

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: ...That sounds a little crazy. But - it's a throwback, but remember, the third one is coming out in 2020, in March of 2020. They just announced it.

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: And it might take you until next summer to finish "Wolf Hall," to be ready.

transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: So this is - I want to correct the misapprehension that this is a hard book to read. This is a - like, a - certainly a long piece of psychologically realistic fiction. transcript.speaker: Barrie Hardymon
transcript.text: That's right. There's literally a picture of Lin-Manuel Miranda on the beach reading that, but it's an old...

transcript.speaker: Susan Davis
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.text: In any case, yes. So there's a wonderful book that I think actually kind of brings together a lot of our - of our genres. And it's called "Murder By The Book." It's by Claire Harman. And it's about a murder in Victorian London in which a minor aristocrat is murdered by his valet. Now, it actually does sound like fiction, right? It's nonfiction. But what's so wonderful about it is this guy's defense was that he had read a popular novel, and the book made me do it, which is kind of a wonderful thing if you think about what fiction can do. However, it's also this wonderful book about class and how we think about the way that books influence us. Every detail is amazing.
